--- title: "Statistics" subtitle: "A Math? A Science? An Art? Or Something Else?" author: "Isaac Quintanilla Salinas" format: revealjs: touch: false controls: true pointer: pointerSize: 32 incremental: false slide-number: true knitr: opts_chunk: echo: true eval: true message: false warnings: false comment: "#>" revealjs-plugins: - pointer --- ## Statistical Warning ![](https://media.tenor.com/GexFRAjz9XcAAAAC/theres-no-guarantee-it-would-work-south-park.gif){fig-alt="south park scientist in laboratory saying: There's no guarantee it would work" fig-align="center"} ## ![](https://media.tenor.com/BCyqY6leyXcAAAAC/linkin-park-in-the-end.gif){fig-alt="Chester from Linkin Park in \"In the End\" video with text saying: but in the end it doesn't even matter" fig-align="center"} # Statistics ## menti.com 2449 3348 ```{=html}
``` ## Statistics {.smaller} ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} ![](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:4800/format:webp/1*VR-XNA60etBQj-r57knvKA.png){fig-alt="An image cloud of different statistical plots, the word statistics is in the middle with capital letters." fig-align="center"} ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: incremental - With an increasing use of data to make decisions, Statistics has been essential for processing large amounts of data to byte-size information - Statistics is also known as - Data Science - Machine Learning - Artificial Intelligence - So for today, we're asking: **what is Statistics?** ::: ::: ::: ## What does Google say? ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} ### UC Irvine Statistics is the science concerned with developing and studying methods for collecting, analyzing, interpreting and presenting empirical data. ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ### Wikipedia Statistics is a mathematical body of science that pertains to the collection, analysis, interpretation or explanation, and presentation of data, or as a branch of mathematics. ::: ::: ## What does AI say? ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} ### ChatGPT Statistics is a branch of mathematics and a field of study that deals with the collection, analysis, interpretation, presentation, and organization of data. ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ### Google Bard Statistics is the science of collecting, analyzing, interpreting, and presenting data. ::: ::: ## What do researchers say? ::: panel-tabset ## Anthropologist Objectively interpreting data to make meaningful inferences about our predictions. ## Microbiologist Whatever the statistician says. ## Sociologist Gathering the narratives of individuals, groups, or society and telling a story about their past, present, or future. The numbers paint a picture worth many words. ## Political Scientist Using numbers to try to explain behaviors and/or patterns in our world. ## Ecologist Statistics is the way to make sense of the natural world by taking data we collect to identify patterns between variables, and applying statistical theory to make sure we are taking the right approach to data collection and analysis. Also, assess patterns to see if they are reproducible and provide a logical explanation that makes biological sense. ## Mathematician Statistics is the study of data, patterns, and trends. ::: ## What is it? ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} ### Math ![](https://media.tenor.com/5ZfhdHdoK3UAAAAC/incredibles-the.gif){fig-alt="Mr. Incredible yelling. Text includes: Math is Math! Math is Math!" fig-align="center" width="498" height="380"} ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ### Science ![](https://media.tenor.com/qWcKVwjtwAQAAAAC/bill-nye-mind-blown.gif){fig-alt="Bill Nye, waving up dramatically with words Science!!! on image." fig-align="center" width="494" height="380"} ::: ::: ## What does a Statistician say? It is the study of variation and randomness! ::: fragment Using mathematics, we model randomness to characterizes commonality and variation! ::: ::: fragment Using science, we systematically refine models to better fit randomness in data! ::: ::: fragment Using art, when it all eventually fails! ::: ## When it fails?!?! ::: fragment ![](https://media.tenor.com/XtqAqClw6AAAAAAC/yes-yes-professor-farnsworth.gif){fig-alt="Professor Farmsworth from futurama doing a 'yes yes' motion with hand and looking away. Text include Yes, Yes" fig-align="center"} ::: ## Statistics Mantra - George Box ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/GeorgeEPBox.jpg/400px-GeorgeEPBox.jpg){fig-alt="An image of George Box" fig-align="center" width="333"} ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} **All models are wrong,** **some are useful!** ::: ::: ## What is the formal definition of Statistics? Statistics is both the development of mathematical models to be used in real-world data and the analysis of data using existing models. ## Probability Models ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} ![](https://media.tenor.com/h5dDA212OzMAAAAC/cat-catwalk.gif){fig-alt="A cat walking an wearing a tutu skirt. Cat walks like a model." fig-align="center"} ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} - Model observations that follow a new data generating process - Understand its properties - Develop new probability distributions - Known as Probability Theory - Researcher is a Probabilist or Mathematical Statistician ::: ::: ## Data Analysis ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} - Model data with a known probability model - Account for sources of variation and bias - Account for violations of independence and randomness - Known as Statistician or Data Scientist ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ![](https://media.tenor.com/ogsH7Ailje8AAAAd/cat-funny-cat.gif){fig-alt="A cat working on a laptop hissing angrily." fig-align="center"} ::: ::: ## What's the goal of a Statistician? ::: {.fragment style="font-size: 2em; color: red;"} **INFERENCE** ::: ::: fragment Use our sample data to understand the larger population. ::: ::: fragment The data will tell us how the population generally behaves. ::: ::: fragment The data will guide us in the differences in units. ::: ::: fragment Data will tell us if there is a signal or just noise. ::: ## menti.com 2449 3348 ```{=html}
``` ## Was the word cloud a scientific study? ::: fragment YES! ::: ::: fragment We sampled a population! ::: ::: fragment Data was collected! ::: ::: fragment Data was summarized! ::: ## Another Word Cloud ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: ![](img/wordcloud.png){fig-alt="A word cloud about statistics. main words are data, variation, probability, and difficult" fig-align="center"} ## Conducting Inference ![](https://statsandr.com/blog/what-is-the-difference-between-population-and-sample_files/population-sample.png){fig-alt="A population of people is displayed. then pointing to a sample with individuals being sampled from population. Afterwards, there is an arrow pointing back to the population with the words inference." fig-align="center"} ## Are we seeing something or is it just noise??? Are we seeing something different from what was expected? Or is it due to random chance? ## Hypothesis Testing ::: incremental 1. Set up the Null and Alternative Hypothesis 2. Construct a test statistic based on the null hypothesis 3. Construct a distribution of the test statistic based on probability theory 4. Compute the probability of observing the test statistic 5. Make a decision based on the probability ::: ## What if we cannot construct the distribution?!?! ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: fragment ![](https://media.tenor.com/x5dpKrM1U6oAAAAd/vamonos-lets-go.gif){fig-alt="An image showing the Monte Carlo car pulling out from a garage." fig-align="center" width="339"} ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: fragment We bring out the **Monte Carlo** methods! ::: ::: ::: ## Monte Carlo Methods - Monte Carlo Methods are used to construct a distribution function of an obscure test statistic - We simulate a large number of data sets based on the null hypothesis - We construct a test statistic for each fake data set and the real one - We count how many data sets produce a test statistic that is more extreme than the real test statistic - $p=\#\ of\ extreme\ data\ sets\ /\ all\ data\ sets$ ## Overview of Research ::: incremental 1. Ask a question about a population 2. Collect data from a sample 3. Construct and test a hypothesis 4. Draw conclusion about the population 5. Refine your question and methodology ::: ## So, what is Statistics? ::: fragment ![](https://media.tenor.com/P647Itj1axcAAAAC/puss-in-boots-cat.gif){fig-alt="Shows Puss in Boots from Shrek turning around" fig-align="center"} ### For you baby, I'll be anything ::: # My Research ## My Research ::: {.fragment .fade-out} ### Generalized ### Time-Varying ::: ### Joint Longitudinal-Survival Models ## menti.com 2449 3348 ```{=html}
``` ## menti.com 2449 3348 ```{=html}
``` ## Joint Models {.smaller} ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} ### Longitudinal ::: incremental - The analysis of repeated measurements - Adjusting for extra correlation - ie: Following a patient and collecting data at different time points ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ### Survival ::: incremental - The analysis of time-to-event data - Event can be anything - Accounting for censoring - When information is not complete - Don't know the whole time - ie: Following a newly diagnosed cancer patient to death ::: ::: ::: ## Modelling them Jointly ::: incremental - We can follow a newly-diagnosed patient longitudinally until the time-to-event occurs - We can use the longitudinal outcome to explain the survival rate of diseases - We can use the survival model to account for missing not at random in patients ::: ## Case Study A patient is diagnosed with cancer, we want to know if any biomarkers can explain the survival rate of the disease. ::: fragment Are there biomarker levels, that can increase the probability of not surviving the next month or year? ::: ::: fragment If so, can we do something about it to increase their chances of survival. ::: ## Data With $n$ participants, each $i^{th}$ participant has: ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} ### Longitudinal Data - $n_i$ repeated measurements - $t_{i}=(t_{i1}, t_{i2}, \cdots, t_{in_i})^\mathrm T$ - $Y_i=(Y_{i1}, Y_{i2}, \cdots, Y_{in_i})^\mathrm T$ - $X_{ij}=(X_{ij1}, X_{ij2}, \cdots, X_{ijk})^\mathrm T$ ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ### Survival Data - $T_i$: Observed time - $\delta_i$: Censoring status ::: ::: ## Longitudinal Submodels {.smaller} Our longitudinal outcome y can be represented in 2 components: a linear model and an error term. The linear $$\Large{Y_{ij} = m_i (t_{ij}) + \epsilon_i(t_{ij}),}$$ where ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} - $m_i(t_{ij})=\boldsymbol{X}_{ij}^\mathrm T\boldsymbol \beta + \boldsymbol Z_{ij}^\mathrm Tb_i$ - $\boldsymbol X_{ij}$: design matrix - $\boldsymbol \beta=(\beta_1,\cdots,\beta_p)^\mathrm T$: regression coefficients - $b_i \sim N_q(\boldsymbol 0, \boldsymbol G)$ ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} - $\epsilon_i(t_{ij})$: error term at time $t_{ij}$ - $\boldsymbol Z_{ij}$: subset of $\boldsymbol X_{ij}$ - $b_i=(b_{i1},\cdots,b_{iq})^\mathrm T$: random effects - $\epsilon_i(t_{ij}) \sim N(0, \sigmaÂ²)$ ::: ::: ## Survival Submodels {.smaller} $$\large{\lambda_i\{t|M_i(t),X_i\}=\lim_{\Delta\rightarrow 0}\frac{ P\{t\leq T_i

include-after-body:
<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
